title: Nigel Farage says 'British people want some ANSWERS' after London terror attack
text: Play slideshow 1 of 10 And he added: "I do actually think that the moment has come for us to actually point the blame. The problem with multiculturalism is that it leads to divided communities Nigel Farage He went on: "His government even said they sent out search parties to find immigrants from all over the world to come into Britain. Do you know what? I don't think we vetted a single one of them. "The problem with multiculturalism is that it leads to divided communities. It's quite different to multi-racialism. GETTY The former Ukip leader called for tougher vetting of migrants from Muslim nations "That's fine, that can work very happily and extremely well. But we've finished up with very divided communities. "I'm sorry to say that we have now a fifth column living inside these European countries. "What these politicians have done in the space of just 15 years may well affect the way we live in this country over the next 100 years." He said that Britain has “made some terrible mistakes in this country, and it really started with the election of Tony Blair back in 1997, who said he wanted to build a multicultural Britain”. GETTY Wednesday’s Islamist terrorist atrocity in Westminster has claimed three innocent lives "Surely an American audience seeing this horrendous thing happening in Westminster should start to say to itself that when Donald Trump tries to put in place vetting measures, he is doing it to protect your country. "Frankly, if you open your door to uncontrolled immigration from Middle Eastern countries, you are inviting in terrorism." Mr Farage’s words were echoed by his successor as Ukip leader Paul Nuttall who cancelled a key note speech today out of respect to the victims of the attack. GETTY Mr Farage also praised Donald Trump's plan for US immigration Mr Nuttall pointed out that the BBC security editor Frank Gardner has revealed that the security services must now track more than 3,000 Islamic extremists and that there are simply too many to track all the time. This is up from 1,000 a few years ago GETTY Mr Farage’s words were echoed by his successor as Ukip leader Paul Nuttall He said: "It is estimated that more than 400 jihadis have been allowed back to the UK from Syria - this is grossly irresponsible. “With the military defeat of ISIS in Mosul and the likely defeat in Syria thousands of battle hardened terrorists are likely to be fleeing into Europe, with many expected to try to enter the UK. "Nobody who chose to fight for ISIS should be allowed back." Related articles
